Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Virginia Poultry Growers Cooperative, Inc. is dedicated to safe facility operations to ensure the protection of its employee, the surrounding public, and the environment. This commitment is integral to the effectiveness of the site-specific programs and policies developed to prevent an accidental release of hazardous materials. Accident release prevention has been established through the development and implementation of design and installation specifications, operating procedures, maintenance programs, employee training, and continuous improvement practices. The purpose of an accidental release prevention effort is to prevent the occurrence of a highly hazardous chemical incident or to minimize the potential consequences of an accidental release. In the event of a highly hazardous chemical incident or emergency, employees, visitors, and contractors are trained to act according to the site-specific Emergency Action Plan. 

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Virginia Poultry Growers Cooperative, Inc. located at 6349 Rawley Pike, Hinton, Virginia 22831, is a poultry processing and storage facility, operating as VPGC, LLC. For this facility, the Risk Management Program ("RMP") regulated substance present is anhydrous ammonia (ammonia), which is utilized as a refrigerant for the closed-loop mechanical refrigeration systems. The closed-circuit ammonia refrigeration systems provide process cooling and refrigerated warehouse storage capabilities to maintain product quality. Ammonia, when properly used, has proven to be a safe, reliable, and efficient refrigerant, though, because of moderate toxicity and slight flammability, ammonia is considered a highly hazardous chemical.

Due to the operating inventories of the ammonia refrigeration systems, as well as Process Safety Management ("PSM") applicability, this facility is covered under Program Level Three [3] requirements of the RMP r

egulations. The two [2] ammonia refrigeration systems, System A and System B, operate independent of each other, without interconnections. However, for the purpose of RMP, VPGC, LLC manages the systems as one covered process.

The Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative-Case Release Scenario(s)

VPGC, LLC has conducted a comprehensive Hazard Assessment for the Hinton, VA facility to determine and document the Offsite Consequence Analysis ("OCA") of potential worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration systems. The OCA describes the offsite exposure to surrounding areas, and the potentially affected offsite population and facilities from an accidental release based on the site-specific administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each determined scenario.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

VPGC, LLC has taken all necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements established by 40 CFR Part 68 and 29 CFR 1910.119 through the development of a combined Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program for the two [2] ammonia refrigeration systems operating at the Hinton, VA facility. 

The Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program consists of fourteen base elements, which work together to establish an incident-free culture. These elements include of policies and procedures for Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permits, Contractors, Emergency Planning and Response, and Trade Secrets. All program elements are tied together through an established Management System that has been developed to oversee the implementation and practice of the Process Safety and Risk Management Program.

The following

sections briefly describe the elements of the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program established for VPGC, LLC's Hinton, VA facility's ammonia refrigeration systems.

Process Safety Information
The Process Safety Information element provides the guideline for developing detailed information specific to the hazards of ammonia, the process technology, and the ammonia refrigeration system equipment. Information collection enables employers and employees to identify, understand, and plan for the hazards posed by the ammonia refrigeration system to improve processes, process safety, and emergency response. The compiled information shall be used for many purposes, such as developing procedures and training programs. The site-specific information is used as a resource to support the Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA") studies.

Process Hazard Analysis
The Process Hazard Analysis element provides the guidelines for completing comprehensive studies of the ammonia refrigeration system to ensure that potential hazards are identified and controlled efficiently. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in refrigeration engineering and process operations and are re-evaluated at a minimum of every five [5] years. Any corrective actions required as a result of these studies will be undertaken in a safe and timely manner.

Operating Procedures
The Operating Procedures element provides the guidelines and written procedures for safely conducting activities related to the ammonia refrigeration systems. These procedures address various modes of operation including initial startup, normal startup, normal operations, emergency operations, temporary operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and startup following an emergency shutdown or turn around. The information is regularly reviewed for accuracy and is readily accessible to all operators who work with the ammonia refrigeration system.

Training
The T

raining element provides the guidelines for establishing a comprehensive initial and refresher training program to ensure that authorized employees, who are working with the ammonia refrigeration system, are competent in all relevant operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three [3] years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity
The Mechanical Integrity element provides the guidelines and written procedures for maintaining, inspecting, and testing the ammonia refrigeration system equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, piping systems, pressure relief valves, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in the applicable maintenance practices.

Management of Change
The Management of Change element provides guidelines for managing changes, including replacements-in-kind, in ammonia refrigeration system technology, equipment, and procedures. Authorized employees whose job tasks are affected by an ammonia refrigeration system modification are promptly made aware of and offered training for the modification.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
The Pre-Startup Safety Review element provides the guidelines for reviewing startup safety any time the ammonia refrigeration system or any of its components, are opened for repairs, tie-ins, or modifications. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
The Compliance Audit element provides the guidelines for conducting audits of the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the Federal and, as applicable, State regulations, are implemented. A comprehensive audit of the Process

Safety Management and Risk Management Program is to be completed at least every three [3] years. Any corrective actions required as a result of these audits will be undertaken in a safe and timely manner.

Incident Investigation
The Incident Investigation element provides the guidelines for promptly investigating an incident that has resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, an unintentional release of ammonia. These investigations procedures identify the situation leading to the incident, determine root-cause, and define any corrective actions implemented to prevent the release from reoccurring. All incident investigation reports are retained for a minimum of five [5] years.

Employee Participation
The Employee Participation element provides the guidelines for involving employees in the development, implementation, and practice of the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, all employees have access to the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program and related documents, including all site-specific PHA studies.

Hot Work Permits
The Hot Work Permit element provides the guidelines for controlling welding and hot work activities on, or around, the ammonia refrigeration system. Hot work is monitored and managed through a permitting process to ensure individual qualification, a safe environment, and fire watch provisions as necessary.

Contractors
The Contractors element provides the procedures for selecting a qualified contractor and evaluating safety performance when third-party work with, or around, the ammonia refrigeration system is required. Contractors shall be informed of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work with the ammonia refrigeration system and also informed of all the procedures for emergency action should an accidental release of ammonia occur.

Eme

rgency Planning and Response
The Emergency Planning and Response element provides the guidelines for planning and responding to an ammonia incident. Emergency planning and response provisions include procedures for emergency notifications, employee training, and safe evacuation of personnel. All emergency planning and response documents are reviewed regularly for verification of data and revised and updated as necessary to reflect changes in facility operations and personnel.

Trade Secrets
The Trade Secrets element provides the guidelines for maintaining confidential business information in relation to the ammonia refrigeration system and its safe operation.

Five-Year Accident History

Any incident for VPGC, LLC's Hinton, VA facility, which resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of ammonia, has been thoroughly investigated. No incident involving an ammonia release has resulted in onsite deaths, on-site injuries, significant onsite property damage, known offsite deaths, known offsite injuries, known offsite evacuations, known offsite sheltering-in-place, known offsite property damage, or known offsite environmental damage. VPGC, LLC's Hinton, VA facility has not had any ammonia releases that would require reporting as part of the five-year accident history.

Emergency Response Program

In the event of an ammonia release incident or emergency, VPGC, LLC has trained its employees to act according to the site-specific Emergency Action Plan ("EAP"). The EAP includes procedures for the notification of emergency authorities/agencies and the surrounding public, the evacuation of facility personnel, and the first responder duties for trained facility personnel. If emergency response is required, VPGC, LLC has coordinated with Rockingham County Fire and Rescue and the Regional Hazardous Materials Team to ensure local responder awareness and response capacity for the Hinton, VA facility. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

VP

GC, LLC utilizes the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program as a continuous improvement practice to improve ammonia refrigeration system safety through employee involvement, operator training, maintenance practices, and hazard studies. As such, the ammonia refrigeration systems for the Hinton, VA facility are designed, installed, and operated multiple safeguards per industry specific recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices ("RAGAGEP"), including normal and emergency ventilation systems, emergency controls that shut down the equipment if operating limits are exceeded, and PLC controls for system operation. Refrigerant leak detection units and associated alarms are installed throughout the facility to notify employees or offsite personnel in the event of a fugitive ammonia release. 

At this time, no significant changes are planned for the facility or ammonia refrigeration system. VPGC, LLC operates an ongoing program of preventive and predictive maintenance to identify and implement changes that may result in improved safety and operations for the ammonia refrigeration systems. Any corrective actions identified as a result of maintenance activities or Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program practices will be undertaken in a safe and timely manner.
